725152f-a.title: Queens: 27th Avenue - 4th Street
725152f-a.text:
27th Ave., south side, east from 4th Street. The Astoris
Presbyterian Church, whose congregation was organized in 1846, laid
the cornerstone of this church on November 30th of the same year.
In 1848 it was dedicated to the service of God; and in 1857 was en-
larged. Rev. Stead was at one time its rector. The church was
demolished in 1928 and buildings Nos. 4-14 to 4-24 are on the site.
However, the Beers Atlas of Long Island does not show a church on this
site in 1873.
1922.
Eugene L. Ambruster Collection.

725153f-a.title: Queens: 27th Avenue - 4th Street
725153f-a.text:
(1)
Twenty-seventh Ave. (right), north side, east of 4th Street,
showing 417 Twenty-seventh Ave., the home of J. Laroque in 1873.
Twenty-seventh Ave. was opened in 1842.
1922.
Eugene L. Ambruster Collection.
(2)
The same, looking north from Twenty-seventh Ave., showing a
near view also of the L.J. White Mansion in 1873. Stephen Halsey
occupied one of these two homes in 1934.
April 1925.
Eugene L. Ambruster Collection.
(3)
The same, viewed west.
1922.
Eugene L. Ambruster Collection.

724976f-a.title: Queens: 4th Street - 27th Avenue
724976f-a.text:
4th Street, east side, 150 feet south of 27th Avenue, showing
an old house. The dwelling appears on Wolverton's 1891 map, but
ownership is not indicated. Fourth Street was formerly called
Perrot Avenue.
P. L. Sperr  June 2, 1927

724977f.title: Queens: 4th Street - 27th Avenue
724977f.text:
4th Street, at the N.E. corner of 27th Avenue, showing an old
private mansion, having been owned by J. Larocdue in 1873. This
photograph was taken from 27th Avenue, the former Franklin Avenue,
the entrance to the front of the house being on 4th Street, the for-
mer Perrot Avenue.
Ewing Galloway  About 1927

724978f-b.title: Queens: 4th Street - 27th Avenue
724978f-b.text:
4th Street, at, and adjoining the N. E. corner of 27th Avenue,
showing two old mansions. The one on the right, the corner house,
is the J. Laroque home of 1873. View 2 shows the rears of the
mansions, seen from 27th Avenue.
P. L. Sperr  View 1: June 2, 1927
NO REPRODUCTIONS  View 2: March 13, 1931

724978f-a.title: Queens: 4th Street - 27th Avenue
724978f-a.text:
4th Street, at, and adjoining the N. E. corner of 27th Avenue,
showing two old mansions. The one on the right, the corner house,
is the J. Laroque home of 1873. View 2 shows the rears of the
mansions, seen from 27th Avenue.
P. L. Sperr  View 1: June 2, 1927
NO REPRODUCTIONS  View 2: March 13, 1931

724979f-b.title: Queens: 4th Street - 27th Avenue
724979f-b.text:
4th Street, at, and adjoining the N.E. corner of 27th
Avenue, showing two old mansions. The corner house (right)
was owned by J. Laroque in 1873, and the othsr by L. J. White.
The latter was also known as the Homer Whittemore house,
according to E. L. Armbruster. View 3 shows the Whittemore
house only. These homes appear in Wolverton's atlas of 1891,
but ownership is not indicated.
Views 1,2: P. L. Sperr  March 13, 1931
View 3: Eugene L. Armbruster Collection 1922

724979f-a.title: Queens: 4th Street - 27th Avenue
724979f-a.text:
4th Street, at, and adjoining the N.E. corner of 27th
Avenue, showing two old mansions. The corner house (right)

724980f-b.title: Queens: 4th Street - 27th Avenue
724980f-b.text:
4th Street, east side, at 27th Avenue. The house on the
Nright is at the S.E. corner of the intersection and is on the
former property of the Astoria Presbyterian Church, whose place
of worship stood in rear of the house. The house to the left,
at the N.E. corner, with the cupola, was the house of J. Laroque
in 1873. The third house was owned by L. J. White in 1873.
These houses do not appear in Beers's 1873 atlas of Long Island;
the authority for the above data Weing E. L. Armbruster.
View 2 shows the S.E. corner house.
View 1: Eugene L. Armbruster Collection  April, 1925
View 2: P. L. Sperr
NO REPRODDNICTIONS  March 13, 1931

View 1: Eugene L. Armbruster Collection  April, 1925
View 2: P. L. Sperr
NO REPRODDNICTIONS  March 13, 1931

724981f-b.title: Queens: 4th Street - 27th Avenue
724981f-b.text:
4th Street, at the N. E. corner of 27th Avenue, showing
the J. Laroque house of 1873. E. L. Armbruster, who took
other photographs of this mansion, states that it was the
Laroque home in 1873, though it does not appear on Beers's
1873 map of Long Island. It first appears on Wolverton's
1891 map.
P. L. Sperr  View 1: June 2, 1927
NO REPRODUCTIONS  Views 2,3: March 13, 1931

724982f-a.title: Queens: 4th Street - 27th Avenue
724982f-a.text:
4th Street, at the aorth-east, corner of 27th Avenue,
showing the J. Laroque house of 1873.
George O. Chinn  April 27, 1940
